document_metadata.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Under both physiological conditions and cellular stress the unfolded protein response (UPR) embodies a conserved reaction ensuring protein quality control and cell survival.[1]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Under both physiological conditions and cellular stress the unfolded protein response (UPR) embodies a conserved reaction ensuring protein quality control and cell survival.[1]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: The UPR either results in reinstating cell homeostasis or consigning them to apoptosis; the adaptive processes are represented by ER associated biogenesis, the ubiquitin-proteasome system and autophagy.[4]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Glucose related protein (GRP) 78, alternatively called BiP is an ER chaperone, closely associated with the launching of UPR, and is among the best studied in this family of proteins.[7]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Conversely, when this compensatory mechanism is overwhelmed, the pro-apoptotic branch of the UPR is triggered by activated PERK; initially it dampens overall protein translation by phosphorylating the eukaryotic initiation factor 2alpha (eIF2alpha) and decreasing the total amount of secreted proteins in the ER lumen.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Under both physiological conditions and cellular stress the unfolded protein response (UPR) embodies a conserved reaction ensuring protein quality control and cell survival.[1]

links.evidence: Under both physiological conditions and cellular stress the unfolded protein response (UPR) embodies a conserved reaction ensuring protein quality control and cell survival.[1]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: To perform its varied functions, the ER undertakes crucial interactions with other organelles, particularly mitochondria to regulate proteostasis and relegate misshapen proteins to degradation.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: In the case of UPR, mutant proteins are degraded via catabolic pathways characterized by the ubiquitin proteasome system and autophagic lysosomes

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: In the case of UPR, mutant proteins are degraded via catabolic pathways characterized by the ubiquitin proteasome system and autophagic lysosomes

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: As an integral function, the ER wields the unfolded protein response to protect the cell from toxicity of accumulated unfolded/ misfolded proteins, whereas mitochondria also have their own protein quality control system, the UPR (mt).[3]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: As an integral function, the ER wields the unfolded protein response to protect the cell from toxicity of accumulated unfolded/ misfolded proteins, whereas mitochondria also have their own protein quality control system, the UPR (mt).[3]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: When the misshapen protein load increases in ER lumen, GRP78 dissociates from trans-membrane sensors kicking off the UPR.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: ER buildup of unfolded proteins may be caused by such diverse factors as genetic defects in protein folding, posttranslational modifications, intracellular calcium alterations, redox imbalance, and inflammatory signaling.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: ER related stress mechanisms are incriminated in numerous human diseases including neuropsychiatric disorders, diabetes mellitus, cancer, cardiovascular, kidney, and pulmonary diseases.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Glucose related protein (GRP) 78, alternatively called BiP is an ER chaperone, closely associated with the launching of UPR, and is among the best studied in this family of proteins.[7]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: When the misshapen protein load increases in ER lumen, GRP78 dissociates from trans-membrane sensors kicking off the UPR.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: The mediators of UPR are three bona fide effectors namely, inositol-requiring enzyme 1 (IRE1), activating transcription factor 6 (ATF6), and protein kinase RNA-like ER kinase (PERK) that regulate a multifaceted cascading pathway.[6]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: The endonuclease action of IRE1 catalyzes the splicing of XBP1 mRNA, causing the formation of an active transcription factor that regulates the expression of genes involved in the execution of UPR

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Indeed, the endoribonuclease cuts out a 26 bp intron from the pre-mRNA of XBP-1 resulting in the formation of a dynamic transcription factor.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Moreover, it has been revealed lately that the ubiquitin- specific protease 14 was instrumental in the catabolism of misfolded Htt by recruiting IRE1alpha and modulating the proteasome function, further adding to the complexity of HD pathology.[43]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: The mediators of UPR are three bona fide effectors namely, inositol-requiring enzyme 1 (IRE1), activating transcription factor 6 (ATF6), and protein kinase RNA-like ER kinase (PERK) that regulate a multifaceted cascading pathway.[6]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: In this regard, ATF6 leads to the transcription of main ER chaperones and X-box binding protein-1 (XBP1).

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: The activation of ATF6 is different from IRE1alpha and PERK, as initially its translocation takes place from the ER to the Golgi apparatus.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: ATF6 akin to IRE1 induces gene expression of ER chaperons, ERAD constituents and XBP-1.[15]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: ATF6 akin to IRE1 induces gene expression of ER chaperons, ERAD constituents and XBP-1.[15]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Experiments demonstrated that the deficiency of ATF6 caused a plummeting of BiP and other ER chaperone levels, retarded the folding and secretion of pro-collagen, and gravely impaired the formation of vital organs.[16]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Experiments demonstrated that the deficiency of ATF6 caused a plummeting of BiP and other ER chaperone levels, retarded the folding and secretion of pro-collagen, and gravely impaired the formation of vital organs.[16]

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: ATFS-1 aids in cross-talk between mitochondria and nucleus; it is typically conveyed to the former, but under conditions of cellular stress the mitochondrial import mechanism is malfunctioning which increases ATFS-1 in the nucleus, causing expression of UPR (mt)-linked genes.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Contrarily, in an AD mouse model, dampening of PERK activity decreases the p-eIF2alpha levels and ameliorates memory deficits.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Contrarily, decreased activity of the PERK or increased expression of the GADD34 phosphatase reduces the level of p-eIF2alpha, resulting in improved synaptic functioning.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: LTP is also influenced by the phosphorylation state of eIF2alpha which is controlled by PERK.

links.evidence: Contrarily, decreased activity of the PERK or increased expression of the GADD34 phosphatase reduces the level of p-eIF2alpha, resulting in improved synaptic functioning.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Additionally, when salubrinal (an inhibitor of PPP1R15A/GADD34 phosphatase) was given to genetically engineered mice over expressing misfolded alpha-synuclein , p-eIF2alpha levels were increased, which was neuro-protective, signifying that the PERK pathway contributed to dopamine neuron degeneration. [37].

links.evidence: Furthermore, XBP1 may also be implicated in crucial neuronal functions, including the formation of memories and new learning.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) is important in the vital processes regulating neuronal plasticity and long-term potentiation (LTP), and varying expression of XBP1 is incriminated in this function.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: Investigations into prototypes of HD revealed that the silencing of XBP1 was neuro-protective by decreasing the aggregation of the misshapen Huntingtin protein (Htt) and promoting the existence of neurons.

citation.name: Endoplasmic Reticulum Stress: Implications for Neuropsychiatric Disorders.

links.evidence: In mouse models of prion diseases, UPR and the PERK pathway are highly stimulated and a persistent rise in phospho-eIF2alpha decreases the production of synaptic proteins leading to the loss of neurons.
